intro: Brassica tyrrhena, commonly known as the wild cabbage, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes other well-known plants like broccoli and cauliflower. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and features basal leaves that are lobed or heart-shaped. Its flowers are small, yellow, and arranged in racemes, typical of the mustard family. Brassica tyrrhena is often found in disturbed soils and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including roadsides and fields.
